column1: ace>Space Ace>1984>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Cinematronics>Advanced Microcomputer Systems>Adventure>3.5>1-2 Players>"The object of the game is not only to rescue Kimberly
column2: but also help Dexter regain his manhood by becoming Ace again
column4: defeating Borf and saving the Earth. As you journey through outer space on this perilous quest
column5: you will encounter all kinds of dangers with enemy spaceships
column6: alien creatures and other nemesis.You make all the decisions on the game as you direct either Dexter or Ace with the joystick depending where you are at. The button does not only make Dexter or Ace fire his blaster
column7: but it can also transform Dexter into Ace at certain parts of the game whenever the word ""Energize"" appears on the screen
column8: but that is only if you choose to do so.If you make it to the end of the game
column9: Dexter will be Ace again for good
column10: he and Kimberly will be reunited
column11: Borf will be turned into a baby by his own weapon (now destroyed) and the Earth will be safe. Afterwards
column12: the game ends. Contrary to popular belief
column13: both Dragon's Lair and Space Ace did contain diagonal movements. In some cases
column14: these movements were simply the combination of two acceptable moves
column15: while in other cases the diagonal move was distinct (for example
column16: during the whirlpool segment in Dragon's Lair moving right or left is acceptable
column17: moving diagonal up-right or up-left is acceptable
column18: but simply moving up results in death). In all cases
column20: and there was always a 4-way alternative. The '91 re-release of Space Ace contained some diagonal moves that were required."

column1: astron>Astron Belt>1983>ESRB - K-A (Kids to Adults)>Bally Midway>Sega>Shoot-'Em-Up>3.6>1 Player>"Astron Belt is an early laserdisc video game and third-person space combat rail shooter
column2: released in 1983 by Sega in Japan and licensed to Bally Midway for release in the United States. Developed in 1982
column3: it is commonly cited as the first laserdisc game. Astron Belt is basically an enhanced version of the simple space-shooters that were popular at the time. The player controls a lone spacecraft on a mission to singlehandedly take down the entire enemy armada. Enemy fighters and ships shoot at the player
column4: and there are mines and other objects that must be shot or avoided. The game is divided into waves. At the end of each wave is a command ship that must be destroyed. In later waves the enemy fighters move and shoot more aggressively
column5: and their shots are more accurate. Some waves take place in open space
column6: while others require the player to battle enemies while flying through narrow trenches and tunnels. The player is on a timer at the beginning of the game
column7: with an unlimited number of lives available. The length of the timer can be adjusted by the machine operator
column8: but is normally 60 seconds. After the timer expires
column9: the player is given a limited number of additional lives. When all of those lives are lost
column10: the game ends.Astron Belt came in both upright and cockpit cabinets. The cockpit version featured illuminated buttons on the control panel
column11: a larger 25"" monitor (the upright used a standard 19"")

column1: badlands>Badlands>1984>ESRB - T (Teen)>Konami>Konami>Adventure>3.6>1-2 Players>Badlands continued the Super Sprint lineage
column2: but moved the game into a futuristic post-apocalyptic setting. The races consist of 3 souped-up cars toughing it out over 4 laps on one of the 8 tracks
column3: which are viewed from above. Two human players can take part
column4: but only the winner continues without using up credits
column5: so you will only see the early races in two-player mode.  You are armed with guns
column6: which can be used to slow opposing cars. During the races spanners can be collected
column7: which are then cashed in for upgraded turbos
column8: improved weaponry and engine upgrades. Hazards on the later tracks include ramps
column10: buildings collapsing onto the track and barriers which open and close in a random sequence.

column1: cliff>Cliff Hanger>1983>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Stern>Stern>Adventure>4.2>1-2 Players>Cliff is on a mission to save Clarissa from being forced to marry the evil Count Draco. Cliff Hanger is an interactive cartoon movie. The game consists of animated scenes

column1: cobraab>Cobra Command>1988>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Data East>Data East>Flying>4.5>1-2 Players>"Cobra Command is an arcade conversion of a helicopter shooting game from Data East. It is an ""on rails"" style shooter with the player controlling only the aiming of the shooting but not the direction of the helicopter.  Your job is to shoot down the enemies as you are flown through footage of New York streets
column6: the treacherous corners and return fire of the enemy's stronghold on Easter Island.There is no background music to go along with the sound effects. The levels are fairly short with a total game run through possible in about 20 minutes."

column1: galaxy>Galaxy Ranger>1983>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Bally Midway>Sega>Shoot-'Em-Up>2.9>1 Player>The game is divided into different waves. At the end of a wave there is a command ship which must be destroyed. Some waves required the player to maneuver their fighter through a trench while trying to destroy enemy fighters. With each successive wave the enemy fighters became more aggressive and accurate with their shots.The first 60 seconds of game play are penalty free
column2: meaning that your fighter can be repeatedly destroyed without the game ending. After 60 seconds
column4: the game is over unless an extra ship was earned. The enemy fighters are all laser disc generated along with the backgrounds
column5: except for the mines. Enemy fighters shots are computer generated and come from the fighters as they move around the screen. Results in a greater interactivity of the laser disc video and makes game play less linear.

column1: gpworld>GP World>1984>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Bally Midway>Sega>Driving>2.5>1-2 Players>GP World has a simple premise: the player must race against the clock and computer-controlled Formula 1 opponents in a series of races. Along the way
column2: the player will earn points to upgrade various aspects of his machine
column4: top speed and handling. The game also includes a track editor
column5: which allows players to create their own courses.

column1: hayate>Ninja Hayate>1984>ESRB - T (Teen)>Taito>Taito>Adventure>3.5>1-2 Players>The game tells the story of a skilled and daring teenage ninja named Hayate
column2: infiltrating an evil castle in an attempt to rescue a princess he loves.[3] Hayate must survive a collection of deathtraps and defeat a variety of mythological creatures and other adversaries on his quest to save the princess and destroy the castle. The game draws players to guide Hayate with a joystick for moving him around and one button for using weapons through 15 different stages that take place in feudal Japan-based areas. There are three difficulty levels. Like earlier laserdisc games such as Don Bluth's Dragon's Lair
column3: Ninja Hayate contains traps and creatures that requires players to dodge or attack them at specific moments
column4: by watching for the warning buzzer (like Dragon's Lair) in addition to flashing objects (e.g. arrows
column7: etc.). If a player makes a mistake
column9: and when players run out of lives
column10: the game ends.Unlike Don Bluth's laserdisc games
column11: Ninja Hayate is animated with anime drawings by Toei Animation. Another difference is that the game flashes the buttons that need to be pressed directly on the screen. Sometimes it also flashes multiple possible button presses on screen
column12: indicating different paths that the player can take.

column1: interstellar>Interstellar>1983>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Funai>Funai>Shoot-'Em-Up>3.2>1 Player>"You are Frald Rancer and control a space ship which must journey from your home planet to outer space to defeat enemy invaders. Once all the enemies are defeated then return home. The game moves in a forward direction where the screen objects move towards and down to the player. Approaching enemy ships are small
column3: and become larger and move faster as they approach the player. The player controls a fighter at the bottom of the screen
column4: which can only move from side to side. Shots can be fired at a diagonal
column6: by twisting the joystick from side to side. At certain stages
column7: ground targets will appear and can be destroyed by using the ""Burn"" button. The laser disc generated backgrounds are largely non-interactive during game play. They form the backgrounds on which the game is played on. Scenes do work in with the backgrounds
column8: however that is the extent. Some backgrounds appear as they should have elements of interactively
column10: were not used in the release of the game. These include scenes where the player is going through an asteroid field and asteroids fly towards the player. Another scene is in the crystal caverns
column11: where there are many obstacles which could have been made to be avoided. These are only two of many scenes which could have had interactive elements. The game may have been decided to have been too hard to play with these background obstacles and computer fighters to play. Hence removing the background interactively to make the game more playable. The game starts with the player in Frald Rancer's home city
column12: then taking off into outer space via a fly-by of the city. The backgrounds are very Sci-Fi and are fantasy themed. They are very interesting
column13: more so than the game. The music from the laser disc also complements the laser disc video very well and makes up for the sometimes annoying

column1: lair>Dragons Lair>1983>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Cinematronics>Cinematronics>Adventure>3.7>1-2 Players>Originally released in the arcades as a laserdisc game
column2: Dragon's Lair is an interactive cartoon movie. Players control Dirk the Daring as he struggles his way through a dungeon to fight Singe
column4: and rescue the beautiful Princess Daphne. The game consists of animated scenes
column5: during which the player has to press direction buttons or the sword button in the right moment to trigger the next segment of the movie.

column1: lair2>Dragons Lair 2>1991>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Leland>Leland>Adventure>3.7>1-2 Players>"Time Warp is a port of the arcade sequel to the original Dragon's Lair arcade game. Players once again play Dirk the Daring
column4: with a little bit of skill and a lot of luck
column5: must once again rescue his princess
column7: Daphne has been kidnapped through a ""wrinkle in time"" by the evil wizard Mordroc and it's up to Dirk to rescue her before she is forced into marriage. The game features every scene that was in the arcade version including scenes based on Alice in Wonderland and other classic fairy tales. The PlayStation 3 and the iPhone version have an original game mode as well as a Director’s Cut with a different ending that was not featured in the original arcade version. The Macintosh version also contains the Director's Cut ending. In the Watch Game mode the entire game can be viewed in full as a movie without input from the player."

column1: mach3>M.A.C.H. 3>1983>ESRB - E (Everyone)>Mylstar>Mylstar>Flying>4.0>1 Player>Gamers have the choice to face off against enemy planes and ground targets as a fighter
column2: or to fly at high altitude over arial targets as a bomber. Using an elaborate flight stick
column3: they can fire a machine gun at the targets as well as launch missiles as they infiltrate the enemy landscape. Targets to be destroyed are surrounded by a computer generated yellow box.  The fighter sequences are generally low-flying affairs as the player must avoid the scenery while blowing up ground targets and shooting oncoming enemy planes and missiles. Taking the other choice
column4: the bomber drops its payload on ground targets and destroys enemy fighters with its machine gun fire. Players are warned of approaching planes by a red warning signal at the top of the screen. Since the enemy country seems to have had some kind of nuclear mishap
column5: the game later provides radioactive clouds for players to avoid. If they can survive till the end
column6: the game takes 15 minutes to complete with a finale airport landing.
